verses.text: All the congregation of the Israelites set out from the Wilderness of Sin, moving from place to place as the LORD commanded. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.comment: Remains close to the Hebrew text; 'moving from place to place' renders the idea of 'journeyed according to their stages.'

verses.text: So the people quarreled with Moses and said, “Give us water to drink.” But Moses said to them, “Why do you quarrel with me? Why do you test the LORD?”
verses.comment: 'Quarreled' can also be rendered 'contended'; 'test the LORD' preserves the sense of challenging God's provision.

verses.text: But the people were thirsty for water there, and they grumbled against Moses, and said, “Why did you bring us out of Egypt, to kill us and our children and our livestock with thirst?”
verses.comment: Modern English rendering of the original complaint, faithful to the Hebrew.

verses.text: So Moses cried to the LORD, saying, “What shall I do with this people? They are almost ready to stone me!”
verses.comment: 'Cried to the LORD' stays true to Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, “Pass on before the people, and take with you some of the elders of Israel, and take the staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
verses.comment: 'Pass on before' translates the Hebrew 'avor lifnei', meaning 'go ahead of' or 'pass on in front of.'

verses.text: Behold, I will stand before you there on the rock at Horeb, and you shall strike the rock, and water will come out of it, and the people will drink.” Moses did so in the sight of the elders of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Behold' is rendered for the Hebrew 'hinneh'; 'I will stand before you' keeps the direct wording.

verses.text: And he called the name of the place Massah and Meribah, because of the quarreling of the Israelites, and because they tested the LORD by saying, “Is the LORD among us or not?”
Then Amalek came and fought with Israel at Rephidim.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering; 'Amalek' refers to the Amalekites, descendants of Esau.

verses.text: So Moses said to Joshua, “Choose men for us and go out, fight with Amalek. Tomorrow I will stand on top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand.”
verses.comment: 'Choose men for us' closely matches the Hebrew imperative.

verses.text: So Joshua did as Moses told him and fought with Amalek, while Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
verses.comment: This is the first mention of 'Hur' in Exodus.

verses.text: Whenever Moses held up his hand, Israel prevailed; and whenever he lowered his hand, Amalek prevailed.
verses.comment: 'Hand' (singular) follows the Hebrew; some versions pluralize.

verses.text: But Moses’ hands grew tired, so they took a stone and put it under him, and he sat on it, while Aaron and Hur held up his hands, one on one side, the other on the other side. So his hands were steady until the going down of the sun.
And Joshua overwhelmed Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword.
Then the LORD said to Moses, “Write this as a memorial in a book and repeat it in the ears of Joshua, that I will utterly blot out the memory of Amalek from under heaven.”
And Moses built an altar and called its name The LORD Is My Banner,
verses.comment: 'The LORD Is My Banner' translates 'YHWH Nissi.'

verses.text: and he said, “A hand upon the throne of the LORD! The LORD will have war with Amalek from generation to generation.”
verses.comment: 'A hand upon the throne of the LORD' follows Hebrew text; meaning is debated—may signify 'oath taken.'
